nodes.text: Statistical physics principles applied to a monetary economy explain typical money and income distributions and dynamics of inequality, while state and banking operations produce systematic deviations and crises
Money is a conserved digital accounting token in peer transactions (local conservation in pairwise transfers) and conservation is fundamental to the functionality of money

Under conservation and microscopic time-reversal symmetry of transactions, the stationary distribution of money among agents is the exponential Boltzmann-Gibbs distribution P(m) proportional to exp(−m/Tm)

When transaction rules break time-reversal symmetry (for example multiplicative proportional transfers), stationary money distributions deviate from pure exponential and can become Gamma-like or develop power-law tails

Debt, banking, and state operations alter conservation at system boundaries: peer-to-peer lending conserves money but creates debt obligations; banks create debt (not intrinsic new money) via lending; the state can inject exogenous money by monetizing bonds

Growth of debt is statistically irreversible without explicit limits, causing instability and potential synchronized crises (Minsky moments); interest accrual amplifies divergence rather than stabilizing debt
Boundary conditions (e.g., nonnegative money balances) are essential for reaching a stationary equilibrium; removing lower bounds (allowing unlimited negative balances) prevents equilibrium

Money and wealth are distinct layers: money is conserved digital information exchanged for goods, while wealth mixes monetary and physical layers and can change via price or quantity changes between transactions

Method: kinetic approach using Boltzmann-type equation and its Fokker-Planck limit (drift A and diffusion B) to derive stationary distributions and relate process types (additive vs multiplicative) to exponential or non-exponential stationary forms

Evidence/Result: empirical analysis of US income data shows a two-class structure—majority (lower class) follows exponential distribution; upper tail follows Pareto power law; temporal changes in upper-tail share correlate with market bubbles and Quantitative Easing

Claim/Evidence: commercial banks, by creating deposits against loans, expand deposits in the agent economy but this expansion equals created debt liabilities; reserve requirements are a soft constraint and do not absolutely limit total debt creation

Claim: The state (via the central bank) can inject exogenous money across the system boundary by buying government bonds or monetizing debt, changing total money in circulation and altering distributional outcomes

Claim/Result: The lend-crash-bailout cycle (banks create debt; crises trigger central bank monetization) transfers gains to private financial actors while socialize losses, and monetization by central bank disproportionately benefits the upper class

Conclusion: Applying conservation-law thinking and statistical mechanics clarifies monetary dynamics, explains observed two-class income distributions and inequality spikes tied to bubbles and QE, and highlights that ultimate source of aggregate monetary profit is state money injection
